samples.text: Apache ActiveMQ Exploit Leads to LockBit Ransomware. This intrusion began in mid-February 2024 after a threat actor exploited a vulnerability (CVE-2023-46604) on an exposed Apache ActiveMQ server. The threat actor was able to perform remote code execution (RCE) by using a Java Spring class and a custom Java Spring payload.

Cat's Got Your Files: Lynx Ransomware. The intrusion began in early March 2025 with a single successful Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) logon to an internet-exposed system. Notably, there was no evidence of credential stuffing, brute forcing, or other failed authentication attempts from the source IP, indicating the threat actor likely had valid credentials.

From Bing Search to Ransomware: Bumblebee and AdaptixC2 Deliver Akira. Bumblebee malware has been an initial access tool used by threat actors since late 2021. In 2023 the malware was first reported as using SEO poisoning as a delivery mechanism.

From a Single Click: How Lunar Spider Enabled a Near Two-Month Intrusion. The intrusion began with a single click enabling Lunar Spider to deploy Latrodectus, BruteRatel, and Cobalt Strike over a near two-month period.
Blurring the Lines: Intrusion Shows Connection With Three Major Ransomware Gangs. The intrusion began with SectopRAT and showed connections to DragonForce, Play, and RansomHub ransomware groups.

KongTuke FileFix Leads to New Interlock RAT Variant. Researchers from The DFIR Report, in partnership with Proofpoint, have identified a new and resilient variant of the Interlock ransomware group's remote access trojan (RAT). This new malware uses PHP and is being used in a widespread campaign since May 2025.
Hide Your RDP: Password Spray Leads to RansomHub Deployment. This intrusion began in November 2024 with a password spray attack targeting an internet-facing RDP server.

Another Confluence Bites the Dust: Falling to ELPACO-team Ransomware. In late June 2024, an unpatched Confluence server was compromised via CVE-2023-22527, a template injection vulnerability, first from IP address 45.227.254.124, which just ran whoami and exited.

Navigating Through The Fog. An open directory associated with a ransomware affiliate, likely linked to the Fog ransomware group, was discovered in December 2024. It contained tools and scripts for reconnaissance, exploitation, lateral movement, and persistence.
Fake Zoom Ends in BlackSuit Ransomware. This case from May 2024 started with a malicious download from a website mimicking the teleconferencing application Zoom.

VShell and SparkRAT Observed in Exploitation of BeyondTrust Critical Vulnerability (CVE-2026-1731). On Feb. 6, 2026, BeyondTrust released a security advisory regarding CVE-2026-1731. This vulnerability involves a pre-authentication remote code execution (RCE) issue within BeyondTrust remote support software. Unit 42 is actively investigating exploitation of this vulnerability and has observed attacker activity. The campaign has affected financial services, legal services, high technology, higher education, wholesale and retail, and healthcare sectors in the US, France, Germany, Australia and Canada.

Critical Vulnerabilities in Ivanti EPMM Exploited. Two critical zero-day vulnerabilities (CVE-2026-1281 and CVE-2026-1340) affecting Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) are being actively exploited in the wild. These vulnerabilities allow unauthenticated attackers to remotely execute arbitrary code on target servers.

Phishing on the Edge of the Web and Mobile Using QR Codes. This article explores the misuse of QR codes in today's threat landscape covering QR code shorteners, in-app deep links, and direct APK downloads. Our telemetry reveals an average of over 11,000 detections of malicious QR codes each day.

Nation-State Actors Exploit Notepad++ Supply Chain. Between June and December 2025, the official hosting infrastructure for Notepad++ was compromised by a state-sponsored threat group known as Lotus Blossom. The attackers delivered Cobalt Strike beacon malware and a Chrysalis backdoor via DLL sideloading.

Novel Technique to Detect Cloud Threat Actor Operations. Unit 42 analyzed cloud alerting events across 22 industries between June 2024 and June 2025, focusing on Muddled Libra and Silk Typhoon threat actor groups and their MITRE ATT&CK technique fingerprints in cloud environments.

The Shadow Campaigns: Uncovering Global Espionage. Unit 42 tracks TGR-STA-1030, a state-aligned group operating out of Asia that has compromised government and critical infrastructure in 37 countries. The group uses phishing, a new Linux kernel rootkit called ShadowGuard, VShell, Cobalt Strike, and various web shells.

Why Smart People Fall For Phishing Attacks. This article explores the psychology behind phishing attacks, explaining why people fall for them despite strong defenses. CISA reported that phishing emails are associated with more than 90% of successful cyberattacks.

Privileged File System Vulnerability Present in a SCADA System. This report details CVE-2025-0921, a vulnerability in Iconics Suite (SCADA system) that could create a denial-of-service condition. The vulnerability allows privileged file system operations that attackers can misuse to corrupt critical system binaries.

Understanding the Russian Cyberthreat to the 2026 Winter Olympics. Russia's exclusion from the Olympics may lead to increased cyberthreats targeting the 2026 Winter Games in Milano Cortina. Historical Russian cyber operations against past Olympics include Fighting Ursa's WADA breach in 2016 and Razing Ursa's Olympic Destroyer malware in 2018.
